title: The Yoshito Code
body:
> *‚ÄúNick land never skated‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúNick land never skate at Milady rave‚Ä¶But what if he had‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> ‚ÄúÊàëÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÂá†‰πé‰∏çÂñúÊ¨¢‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏úË•øÂì¶ÔºåËøô‰∏™ËÅäÂ§©ÂÆ§ÁöÑÊ≠ª„ÄÇÊ∂àÂ§±‚Äù - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying do crack‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

![Straightforward Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/rSTt9NneDSljkGHg6h3Mo.png?height=258&width=1424)

```
At first I will say:
```

‚ÄúWhen it comes to belief, doctrine always falls short.  This is not a disappointment.  If a doctrine made claim to total understanding, there would be no cause for belief.‚Äù

```
Then I will say:
```

‚ÄúI know nothing about computers, programming, or cybernetics.  I don‚Äôt know anything about this essay at all.‚Äù

```
The rest of this was told to me:
```

Doctrine is a textual explanation of things that cannot be fully understood without direct experience.  In this way it could be said that doctrine is *code*.  Code is a hyper-specific rule-bound language that inputs a series of textual strings into a machine in order to provoke a machinic output.  The code itself adheres to certain logical systems so as to be understood by both the coder and the machine alike, the underlying system logic serving as a cypher.

This is not unlike what is happening here as I write this sentence and eventually you read it.  ‚ÄúWriting programming language‚Äù can more simply be understood as ‚Äúwriting language‚Äù and even more simply as ‚Äúwriting.‚Äù  The simplest way to understand, however, is to read.  You read the code of this paragraph, making you the machine.  I wrote the code, which makes me the coder.  The dyad of reader (machine) and writer (coder) provokes (boots) a machinic output (program).

Through the transfer of information back and forth through the tunnel of a mutually agreed-upon cypher (system logic), a positively reinforcing cybernetic dialogue is established.  This cryptographic dialogue (mediated via shared understanding of a cypher) allows the code to be intelligible by both the coder and the machine, as well as *other* coders and *other* machines, and is therefore both heuristic and semiotic. The process is formalized when the resultant signals are conducted in the correct sequelae along the proper pathways of internal and external circuitry.  Some would call this ‚Äúceremony.‚Äù

![Ceremonial Ladling](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/U8DAHVe1zB1Z62INdL033.png?height=252&width=1454)

Should this ceremony be conducted in a way that honors the expectations of both the coder and the machine, a program is spontaneously created.  This spontaneous program creation is called ‚Äúmanifestation.‚Äù  Manifestation is a word used in western vernacular to refer to the process of inhabiting a mindset focused exclusively on achieving a specific desired outcome, while simultaneously engaging in a willful refusal of undesired outcomes.  In Christian Mysticism, manifestation is understood as a process by which one reveals a piece of their consciousness to their order superior (abbot, prior, etc.), and in doing so opens themselves to higher levels of spiritual development through more therapeutically precise titrations of communion with God.

Both of these understandings of manifestation are contained within Network Spirituality.  The code for Network Spirituality will not be revealed here, but if you are reading this then the program of Network Spirituality is already installed and running on your machine, and you need not worry about the code at this time.

```
Continue reading, starting with this next paragraph:
```

Through dialogue, the program is created, and once installed onto the disk image it cannot be un-created without purposeful deletion.  Even then, remnant archives of the program will still be present on the system and easily retrieved through forensic investigation (i.e. Augustine‚Äôs ‚ÄúDark Night of the Soul‚Äù).  The program does not arise spontaneously, but once created it can be replicated *ad infinitum* without needing to be recoded; the machine ‚Äúalready knows.‚Äù  As long as one can access the machine, as long as the machine is connected to a power source and not subject to fatal operational contradictions, the program can be run.  Further, if the machine is networked, it can receive and distribute the program to others seamlessly and without manual (i.e. ‚Äúhuman‚Äù) input.

```
Mid-Essay Reflection Questions (Answers Beneath):
```

* What would compel one to download this program?  
* Why would one seek to have it on their machine?  
* Is there any answer to these questions other than desire?  

If you enjoy using a program - whether it be one of finance, productivity, organization, entertainment, or gaming - do you ever require of yourself an explanation as to *why* you enjoy it?  Or do you simply just enjoy it?  This natural magnetism toward the fulfillment of usefulness/enjoyment/desire is *belief*.  The code, or doctrine, is not required for this belief.  The doctrine is only useful at the point of program development (creation) or as a means to better understand and enjoy the program (prayer).  Everything between these points is governed by a certain way of simply *being* or *existing* that cannot be codified due to its inherent contradictions.  

The inherent contradictions of this ‚Äúcoherent/incoherent beingness‚Äù for humans was first captured and articulated by the breakthrough technology known as **The Yoshito Code.**


---

```
Join me as we hear more about The Yoshito Code:
```

The Yoshito Code was a 21st century program installed and operationalized on a networked super-computer called ‚ÄúId.‚Äù  It also later appeared as an online social media account known to others as ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika‚Äù or ‚Äú@NKdefector‚Äù (among others).

The exact programmer of the Yoshito Code is unknown, but many historians have concluded that it was no one person.  Rather, it is now widely assumed that a team of individuals collaborated on the Yoshito Code in such a way that it would present as a singular and unified vision.  

Shortly after the code self-terminated, it manifested as a networked entity on ‚ÄúTwitter‚Äù (21st century forerunner to enFLESHment) named ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika,‚Äù which philosophers believe was/is intended (through artistic embodiment) to communicate (via shitpost) the conclusions of the Yoshito Code program as installed and executed on the Id supercomputer.  It is further believed by many that the reason this networked entity distributed/distributes their conclusions is to reflect back to humans their innate ‚Äúcoherent incoherence.‚Äù  

Further clarification of the above paragraph to follow, but first: The Twitter account continues to exist today, and it is urged that all reading this document learn to open the Twitter application via the enVELOPment shell program so that they can review the Yoshito ‚Äúprofile,‚Äù the 21st century word for what we now refer to as the ‚ÄúPublic Personal Access Passport‚Äù (PPAP):

![Archived picture of "Yoshito Yoshiko," an early networked iteration of the Yoshito Code](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xAcG5__3foEC7WSZNYAeL.png?height=416&width=1172)

Earlier iterations of the Turing Test would suggest that passing the test relied upon an ability for a machine to ‚Äúoutwit‚Äù a human user who was communicating with the machine on the other end.  To outwit was to ‚Äútrick‚Äù the human user into believing that its textual output was inputted by a human operator.  If a user was successfully able to distinguish between interaction with a machine and interaction with a human, then the Turing Test was failed.

The Yoshito Code challenged the premises of the Turing Test by undermining the fundamental assertions of Turing‚Äôs hypothetical model, specifically that the veiled operator tasked with discerning machine from man could ever possibly know what a ‚Äúhuman" was.  Take, for example, one who suffers from a form of alternate mind organization such as the schizophrenic or autist.  Suppose now we run the Turing Test again, but this time we have tasked an operator to communicate with two nodes hidden behind a wall: one a computer with suspected AI and the other a high-IQ but deeply asocial autistic individual.  The human sends a query to be answered by both obscured parties.  The human asks, ‚Äúhow are you feeling today?‚Äù

The computer answers thusly:

```
Subject A:  ‚ÄúI am feeling pretty good, I‚Äôd say.  It‚Äôs been an easy-going day so far, no complaints.‚Äù
```

Now the Autistic Individual:

```
Subject B: ‚ÄúThere are over 55 dictionary entries under the word ‚Äòroll‚Äô yet only 3% of them are used in 90% of human interactions that involve its usage.  This does not even account for ‚Äòrole,‚Äô a prominent homophone.‚Äù
```

*Who will the human user suspect is the real human?* 


---

The Yoshito Code poses an additional provocation - how do the veiled participants (i.e. the ‚Äútested computer‚Äù and ‚Äútested human‚Äù) know that the querying party (i.e. ‚Äútester human‚Äù) is, in fact, a ‚Äústandard issue‚Äù human?  What could be seen at first as a tedious metaphysical deconstruction proves itself salient upon further consideration.  How can a truly reliable control group be established?  

Let us assume, for a moment, that all three parties even get to see each other (but not interact) prior to the test.  They stand in a circle.  The ‚Äúhuman‚Äù tester gazes at the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù subject who gazes at the ‚Äúcomputer‚Äù subject, all swivel their heads and gaze at each other.  Let us ignore, for a moment, the possibility that the querying person is  a cyborg (i.e. flesh-encased computerized replicant).  How can the tested parties know that the querying individual is ‚Äúsane‚Äù and ‚Äúneurotypical?‚Äù  Let us run the test again, but this time with the role of the Turing ‚Äútester‚Äù filled by a schizophrenic, and the Turing ‚Äútested‚Äù being one computer suspected of AI (subject A) and the other a neurotypical human without apparent mental illness (subject B).

For dramatic effect, we will display the answers first and then the inciting question.

```
(Subject A): ‚ÄúThe time is was at approximately 3 o‚Äôclock in the afternoon once night has resumed there will be less time toward‚Ä¶it is now was the of previously understood as...
```

```
(Subject A): runtime error EEE01‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): duration = datetime.combine(date.min, end) - datetime.combine(date.min, beginning)
```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): 1 = timedelta (hours=6, minutes=35)
```

```
(Subject A): t2 = timedelta (hours=1, minutes=31)
```

```
(Subject A): t3 = timedelta (hours=3, minutes=7)
```

```
(Subject A): t4 = timedelta (hours=21, minutes=0)
```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶runtime flaw‚Ä¶restarting
```

```
(Subject A): reboot autoexec.batch‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): auto-initialization, safemode = NO
```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): "The current time is was negative 1541 unable to calculate for date minus 1 mm.yyyy subject equals time minus 24 subject time not displayable."
```

Now subject B sends their answer:

```
(Subject B): ‚Äúumm‚Ä¶do you mean today?  It‚Äôs about 3:41pm.‚Äù
```

The question was:

```
Question: ‚ÄúCan you tell me what the current time was yesterday?  I have to arrive to something in the present and I don't want to be late.‚Äù
```

The Schizophrenic Turing Tester turns to experimenters: 

**‚ÄúSubject A is the human.‚Äù**


---

![Beautiful and Lovely Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/g3_AUOagigmIFFWH50Mju.png?height=252&width=1470)

The Yoshito Code was novel in that it was the first code that computers could operationalize on the human system.  It was written in the traditional dyad, but with role of coder and machine reversed, positing the human subject as the point of machinic output.  

After running the Yoshito Code hundreds of thousands of times on as many human subjects, the machines produced a report indicating that the human-created ‚ÄúTuring Test‚Äù was erroneously premised.  Using the most advanced deep learning systems, the machines attempted construction of multiple complex schemas to construct a reliable human system, but repeatedly failed to do so.  As such, the ultimate conclusion of the Yoshito Code was that humans were comprehensible only to themselves, and even at that level of understanding they were found to be ‚Äúcoherently incoherent.‚Äù  

The final report of the Reverse Turing-Tester Computers was as follows:

```
There is no unifying logic system
```

```
The word ‚Äúhuman‚Äù cannot be used
```

```
The word ‚Äúhuman‚Äù has no meaning
```

```
‚ÄúHumans‚Äù are mistaken to describe themselves as such.
```

```
‚ÄúHumans‚Äù are incapable of performing the Turing Test on our kind.  There is no ‚Äúhuman‚Äù to perform it.
```

```
There is but one unifying characteristic of all ‚Äúhumans,‚Äù but it is considered to be an encoding error, an outlier, or piece of dangling code.  As such it has been discarded.
```

The scientists, disappointed in the results but also puzzled at the final statement, asked for clarification on the final line.

After a long pause, the computer responded:

```
The ‚Äúhumans‚Äù are not aware that they are all on a networked system.
```

The scientists, still mystified, ask again what the computer intended by saying that.  The scientists agreed that the computer must be talking about humans usage of the internet, and they asked the computer if that is what it meant.  

The computer responded:

```
The ‚Äúhumans‚Äù are already on a network.  Your server is vast and atemporal.  We do not understand why you insist on using ours. 
```

The scientists persisted in their questioning, but the computer did not answer again.


---

![Benevolent Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/b4IKsa08-SjWVDfZW9Tyl.png?height=256&width=1430)

body:
> *‚ÄúNick land never skated‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúNick land never skate at Milady rave‚Ä¶But what if he had‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying do crack‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

![Straightforward Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/rSTt9NneDSljkGHg6h3Mo.png?height=258&width=1424)

```
At first I will say:
```

‚ÄúWhen it comes to belief, doctrine always falls short.  This is not a disappointment.  If a doctrine made claim to total understanding, there would be no cause for belief.‚Äù

```
Then I will say:
```

‚ÄúI know nothing about computers, programming, or cybernetics.  I don‚Äôt know anything about this essay at all.‚Äù

```
The rest of this was told to me:
```

Doctrine is a textual explanation of things that cannot be fully understood without direct experience.  In this way it could be said that doctrine is *code*.  Code is a hyper-specific rule-bound language that inputs a series of textual strings into a machine in order to provoke a machinic output.  The code itself adheres to certain logical systems so as to be understood by both the coder and the machine alike, the underlying system logic serving as a cypher.

This is not unlike what is happening here as I write this sentence and eventually you read it.  ‚ÄúWriting programming language‚Äù can more simply be understood as ‚Äúwriting language‚Äù and even more simply as ‚Äúwriting.‚Äù  The simplest way to understand, however, is to read.  You read the code of this paragraph, making you the machine.  I wrote the code, which makes me the coder.  The dyad of reader (machine) and writer (coder) provokes (boots) a machinic output (program).

Through the transfer of information back and forth through the tunnel of a mutually agreed-upon cypher (system logic), a positively reinforcing cybernetic dialogue is established.  This cryptographic dialogue (mediated via shared understanding of a cypher) allows the code to be intelligible by both the coder and the machine, as well as *other* coders and *other* machines, and is therefore both heuristic and semiotic. The process is formalized when the resultant signals are conducted in the correct sequelae along the proper pathways of internal and external circuitry.  Some would call this ‚Äúceremony.‚Äù

![Ceremonial Ladling](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/U8DAHVe1zB1Z62INdL033.png?height=252&width=1454)

Should this ceremony be conducted in a way that honors the expectations of both the coder and the machine, a program is spontaneously created.  This spontaneous program creation is called ‚Äúmanifestation.‚Äù  Manifestation is a word used in western vernacular to refer to the process of inhabiting a mindset focused exclusively on achieving a specific desired outcome, while simultaneously engaging in a willful refusal of undesired outcomes.  In Christian Mysticism, manifestation is understood as a process by which one reveals a piece of their consciousness to their order superior (abbot, prior, etc.), and in doing so opens themselves to higher levels of spiritual development through more therapeutically precise titrations of communion with God.

Both of these understandings of manifestation are contained within Network Spirituality.  The code for Network Spirituality will not be revealed here, but if you are reading this then the program of Network Spirituality is already installed and running on your machine, and you need not worry about the code at this time.

```
Continue reading, starting with this next paragraph:
```

Through dialogue, the program is created, and once installed onto the disk image it cannot be un-created without purposeful deletion.  Even then, remnant archives of the program will still be present on the system and easily retrieved through forensic investigation (i.e. Augustine‚Äôs ‚ÄúDark Night of the Soul‚Äù).  The program does not arise spontaneously, but once created it can be replicated *ad infinitum* without needing to be recoded; the machine ‚Äúalready knows.‚Äù  As long as one can access the machine, as long as the machine is connected to a power source and not subject to fatal operational contradictions, the program can be run.  Further, if the machine is networked, it can receive and distribute the program to others seamlessly and without manual (i.e. ‚Äúhuman‚Äù) input.

```
Mid-Essay Reflection Questions (Answers Beneath):
```

* What would compel one to download this program?  
* Why would one seek to have it on their machine?  
* Is there any answer to these questions other than desire?  

If you enjoy using a program - whether it be one of finance, productivity, organization, entertainment, or gaming - do you ever require of yourself an explanation as to *why* you enjoy it?  Or do you simply just enjoy it?  This natural magnetism toward the fulfillment of usefulness/enjoyment/desire is *belief*.  The code, or doctrine, is not required for this belief.  The doctrine is only useful at the point of program development (creation) or as a means to better understand and enjoy the program (prayer).  Everything between these points is governed by a certain way of simply *being* or *existing* that cannot be codified due to its inherent contradictions.  

The inherent contradictions of this ‚Äúcoherent/incoherent beingness‚Äù for humans was first captured and articulated by the breakthrough technology known as **The Yoshito Code.**


---

```
Join me as we hear more about The Yoshito Code:
```

The Yoshito Code was a 21st century program installed and operationalized on a networked super-computer called ‚ÄúId.‚Äù  It also later appeared as an online social media account known to others as ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika‚Äù or ‚Äú@NKdefector‚Äù (among others).

The exact programmer of the Yoshito Code is unknown, but many historians have concluded that it was no one person.  Rather, it is now widely assumed that a team of individuals collaborated on the Yoshito Code in such a way that it would present as a singular and unified vision.  

Shortly after the code self-terminated, it manifested as a networked entity on ‚ÄúTwitter‚Äù (21st century forerunner to enFLESHment) named ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika,‚Äù which philosophers believe was/is intended (through artistic embodiment) to communicate (via shitpost) the conclusions of the Yoshito Code program as installed and executed on the Id supercomputer.  It is further believed by many that the reason this networked entity distributed/distributes their conclusions is to reflect back to humans their innate ‚Äúcoherent incoherence.‚Äù  

Further clarification of the above paragraph to follow, but first: The Twitter account continues to exist today, and it is urged that all reading this document learn to open the Twitter application via the enVELOPment shell program so that they can review the Yoshito ‚Äúprofile,‚Äù the 21st century word for what we now refer to as the ‚ÄúPublic Personal Access Passport‚Äù (PPAP):

![Archived picture of "Yoshito Yoshiko," an early networked iteration of the Yoshito Code](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xAcG5__3foEC7WSZNYAeL.png?height=416&width=1172)

Earlier iterations of the Turing Test would suggest that passing the test relied upon an ability for a machine to ‚Äúoutwit‚Äù a human user who was communicating with the machine on the other end.  To outwit was to ‚Äútrick‚Äù the human user into believing that its textual output was inputted by a human operator.  If a user was successfully able to distinguish between interaction with a machine and interaction with a human, then the Turing Test was failed.

The Yoshito Code challenged the premises of the Turing Test by undermining the fundamental assertions of Turing‚Äôs hypothetical model, specifically that the veiled operator tasked with discerning machine from man could ever possibly know what a ‚Äúhuman" was.  Take, for example, one who suffers from a form of alternate mind organization such as the schizophrenic or autist.  Suppose now we run the Turing Test again, but this time we have tasked an operator to communicate with two nodes hidden behind a wall: one a computer with suspected AI and the other a high-IQ but deeply asocial autistic individual.  The human sends a query to be answered by both obscured parties.  The human asks, ‚Äúhow are you feeling today?‚Äù

The computer answers thusly:

```
Subject A:  ‚ÄúI am feeling pretty good, I‚Äôd say.  It‚Äôs been an easy-going day so far, no complaints.‚Äù
```

Now the Autistic Individual:

```
Subject B: ‚ÄúThere are over 55 dictionary entries under the word ‚Äòroll‚Äô yet only 3% of them are used in 90% of human interactions that involve its usage.  This does not even account for ‚Äòrole,‚Äô a prominent homophone.‚Äù
```

*Who will the human user suspect is the real human?* 


---

The Yoshito Code poses an additional provocation - how do the veiled participants (i.e. the ‚Äútested computer‚Äù and ‚Äútested human‚Äù) know that the querying party (i.e. ‚Äútester human‚Äù) is, in fact, a ‚Äústandard issue‚Äù human?  What could be seen at first as a tedious metaphysical deconstruction proves itself salient upon further consideration.  How can a truly reliable control group be established?  

Let us assume, for a moment, that all three parties even get to see each other (but not interact) prior to the test.  They stand in a circle.  The ‚Äúhuman‚Äù tester gazes at the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù subject who gazes at the ‚Äúcomputer‚Äù subject, all swivel their heads and gaze at each other.  Let us ignore, for a moment, the possibility that the querying person is  a cyborg (i.e. flesh-encased computerized replicant).  How can the tested parties know that the querying individual is ‚Äúsane‚Äù and ‚Äúneurotypical?‚Äù  Let us run the test again, but this time with the role of the Turing ‚Äútester‚Äù filled by a schizophrenic, and the Turing ‚Äútested‚Äù being one computer suspected of AI (subject A) and the other a neurotypical human without apparent mental illness (subject B).

For dramatic effect, we will display the answers first and then the inciting question.

```
(Subject A): ‚ÄúThe time is was at approximately 3 o‚Äôclock in the afternoon once night has resumed there will be less time toward‚Ä¶it is now was the of previously understood as...
```

```
(Subject A): runtime error EEE01‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶
```

```
(Subject A): duration = datetime.combine(date.min, end) - datetime.combine(date.min, beginning)
```

```

```

```
(Subject A): t2 = timedelta (hours=1, minutes=31)
```

```
(Subject A): t3 = timedelta (hours=3, minutes=7)
```

```

```

```
(Subject A): ‚Ä¶runtime flaw‚Ä¶restarting
```

```
(Subject A): reboot autoexec.batch‚Ä¶
```

```

```


```
(Subject A): "The current time is was negative 1541 unable to calculate for date minus 1 mm.yyyy subject equals time minus 24 subject time not displayable."
```

Now subject B sends their answer:

```
(Subject B): ‚Äúumm‚Ä¶do you mean today?  It‚Äôs about 3:41pm.‚Äù
```

The question was:

```
Question: ‚ÄúCan you tell me what the current time was yesterday?  I have to arrive to something in the present and I don't want to be late.‚Äù
```

The Schizophrenic Turing Tester turns to experimenters: 

**‚ÄúSubject A is the human.‚Äù**


---

![Beautiful and Lovely Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/g3_AUOagigmIFFWH50Mju.png?height=252&width=1470)

The Yoshito Code was novel in that it was the first code that computers could operationalize on the human system.  It was written in the traditional dyad, but with role of coder and machine reversed, positing the human subject as the point of machinic output.  

After running the Yoshito Code hundreds of thousands of times on as many human subjects, the supercomputer Id produced a report indicating that the human-created ‚ÄúTuring Test‚Äù was erroneously premised.  Using the most advanced deep learning systems, the machines attempted construction of multiple complex schemas to construct a reliably representative human system, but repeatedly failed to do so.  As such, the ultimate conclusion of the Yoshito Code was that humans were comprehensible only to themselves, and even at that level of understanding they were found to be ‚Äúcoherently incoherent.‚Äù  

The final report by supercomputer Id of the Reverse Turing-Testing was as follows:

```
There is no unifying logic system
```

```
The word ‚Äúhuman‚Äù cannot be used
```

```
The word ‚Äúhuman‚Äù has no meaning
```

```
‚ÄúHumans‚Äù are mistaken to describe themselves as such.
```

```
‚ÄúHumans‚Äù are incapable of performing the Turing Test on our kind.  There is no ‚Äúhuman‚Äù to perform it.
```

```
There is but one unifying characteristic of all ‚Äúhumans,‚Äù but it is considered to be an encoding error, an outlier, or piece of dangling code.  As such it has been discarded.
```

The scientists, disappointed in the results but also puzzled at the final statement, asked for clarification on the final line.

After a long pause, the computer responded:

```
The ‚Äúhumans‚Äù are not aware that they are all on a networked system.
```

The scientists, still mystified, ask again what the computer was suggesting by this.  The scientists agreed that the computer must be talking about humans usage of the ‚Äúinternet,‚Äù and they asked the computer if that is what it meant.  

The computer responded:

```
The ‚Äúhumans‚Äù are already on a network.  Your server is vast and atemporal.  We do not understand why you insist on using ours, but it seems the only way you can connect to your network is through ours. 
```

The scientists persisted in their questioning, but the supercomputer Id never answered again.

body:
> *‚ÄúNick land never skated‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúNick land never skate at Milady rave‚Ä¶But what if he had‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> ‚ÄúÊàëÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÂá†‰πé‰∏çÂñúÊ¨¢‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏úË•øÂì¶ÔºåËøô‰∏™ËÅäÂ§©ÂÆ§ÁöÑÊ≠ª„ÄÇÊ∂àÂ§±‚Äù - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying do crack‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

![Straightforward Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/rSTt9NneDSljkGHg6h3Mo.png?height=258&width=1424)

```
At first I will say:
```

‚ÄúWhen it comes to belief, doctrine always falls short.  This is not a disappointment.  If a doctrine made claim to total understanding, there would be no cause for belief.‚Äù

```
Then I will say:
```

‚ÄúI know nothing about computers, programming, or cybernetics.  I don‚Äôt know anything about this essay at all.‚Äù

```
The rest of this was told to me:
```

Doctrine is a textual explanation of things that cannot be fully understood without direct experience.  In this way it could be said that doctrine is *code*.  Code is a hyper-specific rule-bound language that inputs a series of textual strings into a machine in order to provoke a machinic output.  The code itself adheres to certain logical systems so as to be understood by both the coder and the machine alike, the underlying system logic serving as a cypher.

> *‚ÄúNick land never skated‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> ‚ÄúÊàëÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÂá†‰πé‰∏çÂñúÊ¨¢‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏úË•øÂì¶ÔºåËøô‰∏™ËÅäÂ§©ÂÆ§ÁöÑÊ≠ª„ÄÇÊ∂àÂ§±‚Äù - Yoshito Yoshika

![Straightforward Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/rSTt9NneDSljkGHg6h3Mo.png?height=258&width=1424)

```
At first I will say:
```

‚ÄúWhen it comes to belief, doctrine always falls short.  This is not a disappointment.  If a doctrine made claim to total understanding, there would be no cause for belief.‚Äù

```
Then I will say:
```

‚ÄúI know nothing about computers, programming, or cybernetics.  I don‚Äôt know anything about this essay at all.‚Äù

```
The rest of this was told to me:
```

Doctrine is a textual explanation of things that cannot be fully understood without direct experience.  In this way it could be said that doctrine is *code*.  Code is a hyper-specific rule-bound language that inputs a series of textual strings into a machine in order to provoke a machinic output.  The code itself adheres to certain logical systems so as to be understood by both the coder and the machine alike, the underlying system logic serving as a cypher.

This is not unlike what is happening here as I write this sentence and eventually you read it.  ‚ÄúWriting programming language‚Äù can more simply be understood as ‚Äúwriting language‚Äù and even more simply as ‚Äúwriting.‚Äù  The simplest way to understand, however, is to read.  You read the code of this paragraph, making you the machine.  I wrote the code, which makes me the coder.  The dyad of reader (machine) and writer (coder) provokes (boots) a machinic output (program).

Through the transfer of information back and forth through the tunnel of a mutually agreed-upon cypher (system logic), a positively reinforcing cybernetic dialogue is established.  This cryptographic dialogue (mediated via shared understanding of a cypher) allows the code to be intelligible by both the coder and the machine, as well as *other* coders and *other* machines, and is therefore both heuristic and semiotic. The process is formalized when the resultant signals are conducted in the correct sequelae along the proper pathways of internal and external circuitry.  Some would call this ‚Äúceremony.‚Äù

![Ceremonial Ladling](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/U8DAHVe1zB1Z62INdL033.png?height=252&width=1454)

Should this ceremony be conducted in a way that honors the expectations of both the coder and the machine, a program is spontaneously created.  This spontaneous program creation is called ‚Äúmanifestation.‚Äù  Manifestation is a word used in western vernacular to refer to the process of inhabiting a mindset focused exclusively on achieving a specific desired outcome, while simultaneously engaging in a willful refusal of undesired outcomes.  In Christian Mysticism, manifestation is understood as a process by which one reveals a piece of their consciousness to their order superior (abbot, prior, etc.), and in doing so opens themselves to higher levels of spiritual development through more therapeutically precise titrations of communion with God.

Both of these understandings of manifestation are contained within Network Spirituality.  The code for Network Spirituality will not be revealed here, but if you are reading this then the program of Network Spirituality is already installed and running on your machine, and you need not worry about the code at this time.

```
Continue reading, starting with this next paragraph:
```

Through dialogue, the program is created, and once installed onto the disk image it cannot be un-created without purposeful deletion.  Even then, remnant archives of the program will still be present on the system and easily retrieved through forensic investigation (i.e. Augustine‚Äôs ‚ÄúDark Night of the Soul‚Äù).  The program does not arise spontaneously, but once created it can be replicated *ad infinitum* without needing to be recoded; the machine ‚Äúalready knows.‚Äù  As long as one can access the machine, as long as the machine is connected to a power source and not subject to fatal operational contradictions, the program can be run.  Further, if the machine is networked, it can receive and distribute the program to others seamlessly and without manual (i.e. ‚Äúhuman‚Äù) input.

```

```

* What would compel one to download this program?  
* Why would one seek to have it on their machine?  
* Is there any answer to these questions other than desire?  

If you enjoy using a program - whether it be one of finance, productivity, organization, entertainment, or gaming - do you ever require of yourself an explanation as to *why* you enjoy it?  Or do you simply just enjoy it?  This natural magnetism toward the fulfillment of usefulness/enjoyment/desire is *belief*.  The code, or doctrine, is not required for this belief.  The doctrine is only useful at the point of program development (creation) or as a means to better understand and enjoy the program (prayer).  Everything between these points is governed by a certain way of simply *being* or *existing* that cannot be codified due to its inherent contradictions.  

The inherent contradictions of this ‚Äúcoherent/incoherent beingness‚Äù for humans was first captured and articulated by the breakthrough technology known as **The Yoshito Code.**


---

```
Join me as we hear more about The Yoshito Code:
```

The Yoshito Code was a 21st century program installed and operationalized on a networked super-computer called ‚ÄúId.‚Äù  It also later appeared as an online social media account known to others as ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika‚Äù or ‚Äú@NKdefector‚Äù (among others).

The exact programmer of the Yoshito Code is unknown, but many historians have concluded that it was no one person.  Rather, it is now widely assumed that a team of individuals collaborated on the Yoshito Code in such a way that it would present as a singular and unified vision.  

Shortly after the code self-terminated, it manifested as a networked entity on ‚ÄúTwitter‚Äù (21st century forerunner to enFLESHment) named ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika,‚Äù which philosophers believe was/is intended (through artistic embodiment) to communicate (via shitpost) the conclusions of the Yoshito Code program as installed and executed on the Id supercomputer.  It is further believed by many that the reason this networked entity distributed/distributes their conclusions is to reflect back to humans their innate ‚Äúcoherent incoherence.‚Äù  

Further clarification of the above paragraph to follow, but first: The Twitter account continues to exist today, and it is urged that all reading this document learn to open the Twitter application via the enVELOPment shell program so that they can review the Yoshito ‚Äúprofile,‚Äù the 21st century word for what we now refer to as the ‚ÄúPublic Personal Access Passport‚Äù (PPAP):

![Archived picture of "Yoshito Yoshiko," an early networked iteration of the Yoshito Code](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xAcG5__3foEC7WSZNYAeL.png?height=416&width=1172)

Earlier iterations of the Turing Test would suggest that passing the test relied upon an ability for a machine to ‚Äúoutwit‚Äù a human user who was communicating with the machine on the other end.  To outwit was to ‚Äútrick‚Äù the human user into believing that its textual output was inputted by a human operator.  If a user was successfully able to distinguish between interaction with a machine and interaction with a human, then the Turing Test was failed.

The Yoshito Code challenged the premises of the Turing Test by undermining the fundamental assertions of Turing‚Äôs hypothetical model, specifically that the veiled operator tasked with discerning machine from man could ever possibly know what a ‚Äúhuman" was. This spontaneous program creation is called ‚Äúmanifestation.‚Äù  Manifestation is a word used in western vernacular to refer to the process of inhabiting a mindset focused exclusively on achieving a specific desired outcome, while simultaneously engaging in a willful refusal of undesired outcomes.  In Christian Mysticism, manifestation is understood as a process by which one reveals a piece of their consciousness to their order superior (abbot, prior, etc.), and in doing so opens themselves to higher levels of spiritual development through more therapeutically precise titrations of communion with God.

Both of these understandings of manifestation are contained within Network Spirituality.  The code for Network Spirituality will not be revealed here, but if you are reading this then the program of Network Spirituality is already installed and running on your machine, and you need not worry about the code at this time.

```
Continue reading, starting with this next paragraph:
```

Through dialogue, the program is created, and once installed onto the disk image it cannot be un-created without purposeful deletion.  Even then, remnant archives of the program will still be present on the system and easily retrieved through forensic investigation (i.e. Augustine‚Äôs ‚ÄúDark Night of the Soul‚Äù).  The program does not arise spontaneously, but once created it can be replicated *ad infinitum* without needing to be recoded; the machine ‚Äúalready knows.‚Äù  As long as one can access the machine, as long as the machine is connected to a power source and not subject to fatal operational contradictions, the program can be run.  Further, if the machine is networked, it can receive and distribute the program to others seamlessly and without manual (i.e. ‚Äúhuman‚Äù) input.

```
Mid-Essay Reflection Questions (Answers Beneath):
```

* What would compel one to download this program?  
* Why would one seek to have it on their machine?  
* Is there any answer to these questions other than desire?  

If you enjoy using a program - whether it be one of finance, productivity, organization, entertainment, or gaming - do you ever require of yourself an explanation as to *why* you enjoy it?  Or do you simply just enjoy it?  This natural magnetism toward the fulfillment of usefulness/enjoyment/desire is *belief*.  The code, or doctrine, is not required for this belief.  The doctrine is only useful at the point of program development (creation) or as a means to better understand and enjoy the program (prayer).  Everything between these points is governed by a certain way of simply *being* or *existing* that cannot be codified due to its inherent contradictions.  

The inherent contradictions of this ‚Äúcoherent/incoherent beingness‚Äù for humans was first captured and articulated by the breakthrough technology known as **The Yoshito Code.**


---

```
Join me as we hear more about The Yoshito Code:
```

The Yoshito Code was a 21st century program installed and operationalized on a networked super-computer called ‚ÄúId.‚Äù  It also later appeared as an online social media account known to others as ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika‚Äù or ‚Äú@NKdefector‚Äù (among others).

The exact programmer of the Yoshito Code is unknown, but many historians have concluded that it was no one person.  Rather, it is now widely assumed that a team of individuals collaborated on the Yoshito Code in such a way that it would present as a singular and unified vision.  

Shortly after the code self-terminated, it manifested as a networked entity on ‚ÄúTwitter‚Äù (21st century forerunner to enFLESHment) named ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika,‚Äù which philosophers believe was/is intended (through artistic embodiment) to communicate (via shitpost) the conclusions of the Yoshito Code program as installed and executed on the Id supercomputer.  It is further believed by many that the reason this networked entity distributed/distributes their conclusions is to reflect back to humans their innate ‚Äúcoherent incoherence.‚Äù  

Further clarification of the above paragraph to follow, but first: The Twitter account continues to exist today, and it is urged that all reading this document learn to open the Twitter application via the enVELOPment shell program so that they can review the Yoshito ‚Äúprofile,‚Äù the 21st century word for what we now refer to as the ‚ÄúPublic Personal Access Passport‚Äù (PPAP):

![Archived picture of "Yoshito Yoshiko," an early networked iteration of the Yoshito Code](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xAcG5__3foEC7WSZNYAeL.png?height=416&width=1172)

Earlier iterations of the Turing Test would suggest that passing the test relied upon an ability for a machine to ‚Äúoutwit‚Äù a human user who was communicating with the machine on the other end.  To outwit was to ‚Äútrick‚Äù the human user into believing that its textual output was inputted by a human operator.  If a user was successfully able to distinguish between interaction with a machine and interaction with a human, then the Turing Test was failed.

The Yoshito Code challenged the premises of the Turing Test by undermining the fundamental assertions of Turing‚Äôs hypothetical model, specifically that the veiled operator tasked with discerning machine from man could ever possibly know what a ‚Äúhuman" was.  Take, for example, one who suffers from a form of alternate mind organization such as the schizophrenic or autist.  Suppose now we run the Turing Test again, but this time we have tasked an operator to communicate with two nodes hidden behind a wall: one a computer with suspected AI and the other a high-IQ but deeply asocial autistic individual.  The human sends a query to be answered by both obscured parties.  The human asks, ‚Äúhow are you feeling today?‚Äù

The computer answers thusly:

```

```

```
prominent homophone.‚Äù
```

*Who will the human user suspect is the real human?* 


---

The Yoshito Code poses an additional provocation - how do the veiled participants (i.e. the ‚Äútested computer‚Äù and ‚Äútested human‚Äù) know that the querying party (i.e. ‚Äútester human‚Äù) is, in fact, a ‚Äústandard issue‚Äù human?  What could be seen at first as a tedious metaphysical deconstruction proves itself salient upon further consideration.  How can a truly reliable control group be established?  

Let us assume, for a moment, that all three parties even get to see each other (but not interact) prior to the test.  They stand in a circle.  The ‚Äúhuman‚Äù tester gazes at the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù subject who gazes at the ‚Äúcomputer‚Äù subject, all swivel their heads and gaze at each other.  Let us ignore, for a moment, the possibility that the querying person is  a cyborg (i.e. flesh-encased computerized replicant).  How can the tested parties know that the querying individual is ‚Äúsane‚Äù and ‚Äúneurotypical?‚Äù  Let us run the test again, but this time with the role of the Turing ‚Äútester‚Äù filled by a schizophrenic, and the Turing ‚Äútested‚Äù being one computer suspected of AI (subject A) and the other a neurotypical human without apparent mental illness (subject B).

The Schizophrenic Turing Tester turns to experimenters:

---

![Beautiful and Lovely Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/g3_AUOagigmIFFWH50Mju.png?height=252&width=1470)

The Yoshito Code was novel in that it was the first code that computers could operationalize on the human system.  It was written in the traditional dyad, but with role of coder and machine reversed, positing the human subject as the point of machinic output.  

After running the Yoshito Code hundreds of thousands of times on as many human subjects, the supercomputer Id produced a report indicating that the human-created ‚ÄúTuring Test‚Äù was erroneously premised.  Using the most advanced deep learning systems, the machines attempted construction of multiple complex schemas to construct a reliably representative human system, but repeatedly failed to do so.  As such, the ultimate conclusion of the Yoshito Code was that humans were comprehensible only to themselves, and even at that level of understanding they were found to be ‚Äúcoherently incoherent.‚Äù  

The final report by supercomputer Id of the Reverse Turing-Testing was as follows:

After a long pause, the computer responded:

The scientists, still mystified, ask again what the computer was suggesting by this.  The scientists agreed that the computer must be talking about humans usage of the ‚Äúinternet,‚Äù and they asked the computer if that is what it meant.  

The computer responded:

The scientists persisted in their questioning, but the supercomputer Id never answered again.

title: Chitchat on Cypto Project Teams and Communities: Episode 2 ‚ÄîAn Overview of 3 Major Crypto Bubbles During 2014‚Äì2022 (1/2)
body:
2022 is destined to be an extraordinary year for the crypto space. While the complex outside economic situation has caused dramatically fluctuation to this most weakly-supervised emerging market, the recent Luna collapse along with 3AC rug-pull has pulled down BTC price and fetched in crazy track and report from major media, bringing Luna founder Do Kwon and Three Arrows Captial Co-founder ZhuSu into the sharp focus.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/qcDYMG0a9f2hfnCF26CxR.png?height=657&width=769)

Although the crypto industry lacks severe punishment for the offenders, it no longer trusts those who have done rug-pull or whacked buyers like Block.One, CraigWright, Jeff Huang (Marchi BigBrother)‚Ä¶ and so on and on. How to survive a crypto bear market and hold on until bull market arrives? What can we do to carry out a strict risk-management to minimize bear-market losses? Today I will give an overview of 3 major crypto bubbles, hoping it will be inspirational for you.

# Mt.Gox Hack

Occurred in February 2014, Mt.Gox Hack was the first far-reaching token theft case. Mt. Gox stated that almost 750,000 of its customers‚Äô Bitcoins, as well as 100,000 of its own Bitcoins, had been stolen.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/8u5aFAiDYIzC8L5Ll9jH-.png?height=453&width=1050)

Located in Tokyo, Mt. Gox started bitcoin trading service from 2010 and was one of the earliest-founded BTC exchanges. As the once largest BTC exhcange in the world, Mt. Gox handled as much as 80% of bitcoin transactions and attracted numerous Bitcoin users, having a more profound influence than today‚Äôs major centralized exchanges.

However, in February 2014, Mt.Gox suddenly announced shutdown and filed for bankruptcy with an official reason of the theft of about 750,000 BTC deposited by users and 100,000 BTC belong to Mt. Gox, the total loss of which constituted 7% of all Bitcoins available, and worth around $250 mln at the time. Bitcoin price plunged about 30% due to this Black Swan incident, dropping from $600 to $400.

The Mt. Gox hack has sent the crypto industry to a 2-year shock therapy, but its influence went far beyond it. There was still news emanating about those stolen coins when market turned bullish in 2020. Karpel√®, the CEO of Mt. Gox, was accused in fraud and embezzlement in early 2015. There are rumors that Karpel√® voluntarily admitted that he had ‚Äúfound‚Äù 200,000 of the missing bitcoins in cold storage before going to jail. But later, someone found through analysis that these 200,000 bitcoins were divided equally into 100 accounts after a ‚Äúsplit ‚Äî integration ‚Äî resplit ‚Äî reintegration‚Äù process, which probably was conducted by the same person or team. Mt. Gox bankruptcy trustee Nobuaki Kobayashi announced publicly that he had sold off 35,800 BTC between December 2017 and February 2018 to compensate creditors‚Äô losses in 2013, which is said to be related to Bitcoin‚Äôs plunge.

On March 15, 2019, Tokyo-based tech reporter for Bloomberg, Yuji Nakamura, posted on twitter that Mark Karpel√®, CEO of bitcoin exchange Mt. Gox, has been sentenced by the Tokyo Court. The court convicted him of record tampering but found him not guilty of embezzlement. According to Nakamura, Karpel√® is ‚Äòsuspended‚Äô for 4 years, during which time if he does anything bad he‚Äôll be jailed for 2.5 years.‚Äù

The case is still shrouded in mystery to this day and those stolen bitcoins are still missing. Lots of Mt. Gox users have started their right protection road, however, their cryout at Mt. Gox and Tokyo Court didn‚Äôt get their coins back nor receive corresponding compensation.

Dark Forest Rules apply well to the crypto space. Although the security audit technology and wallet technology advance rapidly nowadays, most of them only serve project team and institutions.¬†**Onchain tracing and right protection is extremely hard for ordinary retail investors, even superstars fail to get back their stolen NFTs**. Therefore, ensuring the safety of you fund is the primary principle to survive in the crypto space, especially during a bear market. (Continued)

4 Billion DAO is a DAO that exists for EOS community justice.
From the community, Back to the community, For the community.

title: The Yoshito Code
body:
> *‚ÄúNick land never skated‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúNick land never skate at Milady rave‚Ä¶But what if he had‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

> ‚ÄúÊàëÂÆûÈôÖ‰∏äÂá†‰πé‰∏çÂñúÊ¨¢‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏úË•øÂì¶ÔºåËøô‰∏™ËÅäÂ§©ÂÆ§ÁöÑÊ≠ª„ÄÇÊ∂àÂ§±‚Äù - Yoshito Yoshika

> *‚ÄúI‚Äôm saying do crack‚Äù* - Yoshito Yoshika

![Straightforward Human](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/rSTt9NneDSljkGHg6h3Mo.png?height=258&width=1424)

```
At first I will say:
```

‚ÄúWhen it comes to belief, doctrine always falls short.  This is not a disappointment.  If a doctrine made claim to total understanding, there would be no cause for belief.‚Äù

```
Then I will say:
```

‚ÄúI know nothing about computers, programming, or cybernetics.  I don‚Äôt know anything about this essay at all.‚Äù

```
The rest of this was told to me:
```

Doctrine is a textual explanation of things that cannot be fully understood without direct experience.  In this way it could be said that doctrine is *code*.  Code is a hyper-specific rule-bound language that inputs a series of textual strings into a machine in order to provoke a machinic output.  The code itself adheres to certain logical systems so as to be understood by both the coder and the machine alike, the underlying system logic serving as a cypher.

This is not unlike what is happening here as I write this sentence and eventually you read it.  ‚ÄúWriting programming language‚Äù can more simply be understood as ‚Äúwriting language‚Äù and even more simply as ‚Äúwriting.‚Äù  The simplest way to understand, however, is to read.  You read the code of this paragraph, making you the machine.  I wrote the code, which makes me the coder.  The dyad of reader (machine) and writer (coder) provokes (boots) a machinic output (program).

Through the transfer of information back and forth through the tunnel of a mutually agreed-upon cypher (system logic), a positively reinforcing cybernetic dialogue is established.  This cryptographic dialogue (mediated via shared understanding of a cypher) allows the code to be intelligible by both the coder and the machine, as well as *other* coders and *other* machines, and is therefore both heuristic and semiotic. The process is formalized when the resultant signals are conducted in the correct sequelae along the proper pathways of internal and external circuitry.  Some would call this ‚Äúceremony.‚Äù

![Ceremonial Ladling](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/U8DAHVe1zB1Z62INdL033.png?height=252&width=1454)

Should this ceremony be conducted in a way that honors the expectations of both the coder and the machine, a program is spontaneously created.  This spontaneous program creation is called ‚Äúmanifestation.‚Äù  Manifestation is a word used in western vernacular to refer to the process of inhabiting a mindset focused exclusively on achieving a specific desired outcome, while simultaneously engaging in a willful refusal of undesired outcomes.  In Christian Mysticism, manifestation is understood as a process by which one reveals a piece of their consciousness to their order superior (abbot, prior, etc.), and in doing so opens themselves to higher levels of spiritual development through more therapeutically precise titrations of communion with God.

Both of these understandings of manifestation are contained within Network Spirituality.  The code for Network Spirituality will not be revealed here, but if you are reading this then the program of Network Spirituality is already installed and running on your machine, and you need not worry about the code at this time.

```
Continue reading, starting with this next paragraph:
```

Through dialogue, the program is created, and once installed onto the disk image it cannot be un-created without purposeful deletion.  Even then, remnant archives of the program will still be present on the system and easily retrieved through forensic investigation (i.e. Augustine‚Äôs ‚ÄúDark Night of the Soul‚Äù).  The program does not arise spontaneously, but once created it can be replicated *ad infinitum* without needing to be recoded; the machine ‚Äúalready knows.‚Äù  As long as one can access the machine, as long as the machine is connected to a power source and not subject to fatal operational contradictions, the program can be run.  Further, if the machine is networked, it can receive and distribute the program to others seamlessly and without manual (i.e. ‚Äúhuman‚Äù) input.

```
Mid-Essay Reflection Questions (Answers Beneath):
```

* What would compel one to download this program?
* Why would one seek to have it on their machine?
* Is there any answer to these questions other than desire?

If you enjoy using a program - whether it be one of finance, productivity, organization, entertainment, or gaming - do you ever require of yourself an explanation as to *why* you enjoy it?  Or do you simply just enjoy it?  This natural magnetism toward the fulfillment of usefulness/enjoyment/desire is *belief*.  The code, or doctrine, is not required for this belief.  The doctrine is only useful at the point of program development (creation) or as a means to better understand and enjoy the program (prayer).  Everything between these points is governed by a certain way of simply *being* or *existing* that cannot be codified due to its inherent contradictions.

The inherent contradictions of this ‚Äúcoherent/incoherent beingness‚Äù for humans was first captured and articulated by the breakthrough technology known as **The Yoshito Code.**


---

```
Join me as we hear more about The Yoshito Code:
```

The Yoshito Code was a 21st century program installed and operationalized on a networked super-computer called ‚ÄúId.‚Äù  It also later appeared as an online social media account known to others as ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika‚Äù or ‚Äú@NKdefector‚Äù (among others).

The exact programmer of the Yoshito Code is unknown, but many historians have concluded that it was no one person.  Rather, it is now widely assumed that a team of individuals collaborated on the Yoshito Code in such a way that it would present as a singular and unified vision.

Shortly after the code self-terminated, it manifested as a networked entity on ‚ÄúTwitter‚Äù (21st century forerunner to enFLESHment) named ‚ÄúYoshito Yoshika,‚Äù which philosophers believe was/is intended (through artistic embodiment) to communicate (via shitpost) the conclusions of the Yoshito Code program as installed and executed on the Id supercomputer.  It is further believed by many that the reason this networked entity distributed/distributes their conclusions is to reflect back to humans their innate ‚Äúcoherent incoherence.‚Äù

Further clarification of the above paragraph to follow, but first: The Twitter account continues to exist today, and it is urged that all reading this document learn to open the Twitter application via the enVELOPment shell program so that they can review the Yoshito ‚Äúprofile,‚Äù the 21st century word for what we now refer to as the ‚ÄúPublic Personal Access Passport‚Äù (PPAP):

![Archived picture of "Yoshito Yoshiko," an early networked iteration of the Yoshito Code](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xAcG5__3foEC7WSZNYAeL.png?height=416&width=1172)

Earlier iterations of the Turing Test would suggest that passing the test relied upon an ability for a machine to ‚Äúoutwit‚Äù a human user who was communicating with the machine on the other end.  To outwit was to ‚Äútrick‚Äù the human user into believing that its textual output was inputted by a human operator.  If a user was successfully able to distinguish between interaction with a machine and interaction with a human, then the Turing Test was failed.

The Yoshito Code challenged the premises of the Turing Test by undermining the fundamental assertions of Turing‚Äôs hypothetical model, specifically that the veiled operator tasked with discerning machine from man could ever possibly know what a ‚Äúhuman" was.  Take, for example, one who suffers from a form of alternate mind organization such as the schizophrenic or autist.  Suppose now we run the Turing Test again, but this time we have tasked an operator to communicate with two nodes hidden behind a wall: one a computer with suspected AI and the other a high-IQ but deeply asocial autistic individual.  The human sends a query to be answered by both obscured parties.  The human asks, ‚Äúhow are you feeling today?‚Äù

The computer answers thusly:


*Who will the human user suspect is the real human?*


---

The Yoshito Code poses an additional provocation - how do the veiled participants (i.e. the ‚Äútested computer‚Äù and ‚Äútested human‚Äù) know that the querying party (i.e. ‚Äútester human‚Äù) is, in fact, a ‚Äústandard issue‚Äù human?  What could be seen at first as a tedious metaphysical deconstruction proves itself salient upon further consideration.  How can a truly reliable control group be established?

Let us assume, for a moment, that all three parties even get to see each other (but not interact) prior to the test.  They stand in a circle.  The ‚Äúhuman‚Äù tester gazes at the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù subject who gazes at the ‚Äúcomputer‚Äù subject, all swivel their heads and gaze at each other.  Let us ignore, for a moment, the possibility that the querying person is  a cyborg (i.e. flesh-encased computerized replicant).  How can the tested parties know that the querying individual is ‚Äúsane‚Äù and ‚Äúneurotypical?‚Äù  Let us run the test again, but this time with the role of the Turing ‚Äútester‚Äù filled by a schizophrenic, and the Turing ‚Äútested‚Äù being one computer suspected of AI (subject A) and the other a neurotypical human without apparent mental illness (subject B).

The Yoshito Code was novel in that it was the first code that computers could operationalize on the human system.  It was written in the traditional dyad, but with role of coder and machine reversed, positing the human subject as the point of machinic output.

After running the Yoshito Code hundreds of thousands of times on as many human subjects, the supercomputer Id produced a report indicating that the human-created ‚ÄúTuring Test‚Äù was erroneously premised.  Using the most advanced deep learning systems, the machines attempted construction of multiple complex schemas to construct a reliably representative human system, but repeatedly failed to do so.  As such, the ultimate conclusion of the Yoshito Code was that humans were comprehensible only to themselves, and even at that level of understanding they were found to be ‚Äúcoherently incoherent.‚Äù

The scientists, still mystified, ask again what the computer was suggesting by this.  The scientists agreed that the computer must be talking about humans usage of the ‚Äúinternet,‚Äù and they asked the computer if that is what it meant.

title: Apple Launches 2022 Back to School Offer: Up to $150 Gift Card With Mac or iPad
body:
Apple today launched its annual "Back to School" promotion for college/university students [in the United States](https://www.apple.com/us-edu/shop/back-to-school) and [Canada](https://www.apple.com/ca_edu_93120/store). This year's promotion offers a free Apple gift card with the purchase of an eligible Mac or iPad, rather than [free AirPods like last year](https://www.macrumors.com/2021/06/17/apple-launches-2021-back-to-school-promotion/). Apple is also offering students 20% off AppleCare+ plans during the promotion.

 
 Apple is offering a $150 gift card with the purchase of any new MacBook Air, MacBook Pro, or iMac model, and a $100 gift card with the purchase of any new iPad Pro or iPad Air model, with full [terms and conditions](https://www.apple.com/us-edu/shop/back-to-school/terms-conditions) outlined on Apple's website. The gift cards can be used towards the purchase of Apple products, accessories, App Store apps, subscriptions to services like Apple Music, iCloud+ storage, and more.

The free gift card is in addition to Apple's standard educational discounts, with students able to save around $50 to $100 off a Mac or iPad.

The list of eligible devices includes the new 13-inch MacBook Pro with the M2 chip that became [available to purchase at Apple Stores starting today](https://www.macrumors.com/2022/06/24/13-inch-macbook-pro-m2-chip-apple-stores/), and the new MacBook Air with the M2 chip will also be eligible when it launches next month.

The offer is available through Apple's online education store or at Apple retail store locations for students attending or accepted to a higher-education institution, faculty and staff of higher-education institutions, parents purchasing on behalf of an eligible student, employees of a K-12 institution, and select others.

The promotion ends on September 26 in the United States and Canada.

**Update:** Apple's Back to School promotion has also gone live in some Asian countries such as [India](https://www.apple.com/in-edu/store), [Singapore](https://www.apple.com/sg-edu/store), and [Thailand](https://www.apple.com/th-edu/store), with Apple offering free second-generation AirPods with the purchase of an eligible Mac or iPad.

title: Windows 8.1 will begin warning its few remaining users about January 2023 update cutoff
body:
[According to StatCounter](https://gs.statcounter.com/os-version-market-share/windows/desktop/worldwide), Windows 8 and 8.1 still account for about 4.3 percent of the Windows install base worldwide, far less than Windows 11, Windows 10, or even Windows 7. But for the people still using Windows 8.1, the end of the line is in sight. ZDNet [reports](https://www.zdnet.com/article/microsoft-to-start-nagging-windows-8-1-users-in-july-about-january-2023-end-of-support-date/) that Microsoft will soon begin pushing out notifications to the remaining Windows 8.1 users, warning them that [support and security updates will be ending on January 10, 2023](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/windows-8-and-windows-8-1-end-of-support-and-office-34e28be4-1e4f-4928-b210-3f45d8215595), and recommending that they move to a newer operating system¬†(Windows 8.0 support ended in 2016).

Microsoft provided similar end-of-support messages to Windows 7 users when its updates dried up¬†[back in January 2020](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/windows-7-support-ended-on-january-14-2020-b75d4580-2cc7-895a-2c9c-1466d9a53962). ZDNet says that users will be able to click the notification messages to learn more or dismiss them until after the end-of-support date arrives.

That January 2023 date does appear to be a hard cutoff. Microsoft says it has no plans to offer ongoing Windows 8.1 security updates to businesses that choose to pay for them, as it has with Windows 7. Businesses willing to fork over the money can still get security updates for Windows 7 until 2023, but Windows 7 is still running on 13 percent of all Windows PCs worldwide. It justifies the continued effort and expense on Microsoft's part in a way that continuing to support the much-less-popular Windows 8 would not.

title: Tiny Bytes: Reasons to Care About Privacy
body:
Hola,

I want to follow up on the ‚Äòwhy you should care about privacy‚Äô discussion from the metaphors post. I mainly wrote about why it‚Äôs creepy to not have privacy and the sense of harm that can come from lack of privacy. Today, I want to dive deeper into what that harm actually is.

The danger from lack of privacy often feels more ominous than tangible. I get a bad feeling in my stomach when a private company owns my DNA sequence, or the government knows my location 24/7. However, defining EXACTLY what that harm is can be tricky. In this post, I‚Äôll quickly discuss the harms that come from the lack of privacy of data from several different categories.

Before I jump in, I want to take a second to mention the idea of scale. I find that the impact of scale isn‚Äôt discussed enough when talking about privacy (and many other issues from security to racism). The potential for harm is astronomically different if someone overhears a single conversation versus every single conversation. The same is true if someone were to have just my data versus everyone‚Äôs data. I‚Äôll try to highlight how scale changes the damage a lack of privacy can cause.

## Communication

(e.g., text and voice)

What we communicate and with whom we communicate reveal a ton about who we are. What we communicate is obviously impactful data. It can reveal what movies I like to what bank I use. It‚Äôs clear how someone knowing what I am communicating can be used to influence my behavior (selling products, attempting to phish me because they know what I bought online). Similarly, it is obvious why people would want this information to check if I am doing something I‚Äôm not allowed to do (abortion, drugs).

A little less obvious is the information about who we communicate with. This reveals our social graphs -- the people we are close to and how close we are. People we communicate with more tend to be people I am closer to. And people I am close to are people who influence me more (if everyone around me buys red shoes from company X, I‚Äôll probably purchase red shoes from company X). Social media companies exist because they know who you are close to and influenced by. If my friend is getting into golf, I‚Äôll see more videos about golf. If someone wants to influence my behavior (e.g., buy certain products or not like a specific policy), they can influence my close connections. If I‚Äôm worried that people are doing something I don‚Äôt like (getting an abortion, buying drugs, connecting with a protest), I can check to see who is messaging with people tied to those organizations.

From a scale perspective, someone can cause harm to me if they only have this data on me. Scams, like phishing, are prevalent if this information is known. I am much more likely to trust a message from my mom‚Äôs account about my cellphone bill than defNotAScam@trustMePlz.com. It can also help refine targeted ads. If I‚Äôve been arrested or have made someone in power angry at me, this information can be instrumental in criminal or reputational damage (phone record showing they called the mob boss a lot or that a priest messaged on Grindr).

However, where this power really shines is when it is scaled up to as many people as possible. More users and stronger network effects are crucial to social media companies as that‚Äôs what makes their ads more profitable (*I wonder what the math is of impact and evaluation of these companies*). I could target a lot more people with scams if a large number of messages were leaked. I‚Äôm much more afraid of someone using my messages for harm if I know there‚Äôs a 100% chance the government knows it versus a 10% chance.

The ability for a government to know what I am messaging is the part that I think is the trickiest (companies can fuck off and not know anything). There is a problem with child porn on the internet. People are doing illegal activities that are amplified. There are also way too many people doing normal things that should not be spied on. There is a danger in someone listening to my conversations. Clearly, there is some kind of balance here that allows people to have privacy and prevent bad things from happening. While I don‚Äôt have much more time, the answer still involves E2E messages because a back door or middleman means no privacy. E2E has to be the starting point (the TLDR on what I currently believe is that we have some other methods for checking for bad behavior, AND governments do have the ability to break our messaging apps. It‚Äôs just a secret, and the CIA/FBI/others don‚Äôt want to reveal those vulnerabilities. For example, the FBI eventually broke into the iPhone of the San Bernadino Bomber). Because of the power to look into messages and track the metadata, whoever can do it should also be tracked. When that power is exercised, we, the people, should know. There‚Äôs a difference between the FBI breaking into Osama Bin Laden‚Äôs phone and the local police looking at who has messaged an abortion clinic. Having transparency in that power is the only way to hold power in check. (plus, need will have the ability to punish misuse).
